# Composio Docs

## Docs

- [Welcome](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/welcome.mdx)
- [Quickstart](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/quickstart.mdx): Add authenticated tool-calling to any LLM agent in three steps.
- [IDE and Agent Setup](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/dev-setup.mdx): Cursor is an AI-powered code editor that can significantly accelerate your development with Composio. Here's how to set it up optimally.
- [Providers](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/providers.mdx): Think of providers as translators. Different AI frameworks (like OpenAI, Anthropic Claude, or LangChain) expect tools to be formatted in their spec...
- [Executing Tools](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/executing-tools.mdx): For non-agent providers—such as OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google AI—you can process tool calls using the tool call handlers provided by the Composio SDK.
- [Authenticating Tools](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/authenticating-tools.mdx): Each toolkit comes with its own _auth config_.
- [Fetch and Filter Tools](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/fetching-tools.mdx): Toolkits are collections of tools from a specific app!
- [Schema Modifiers](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/schema-modifiers.mdx): Schema modifiers transform a tool's schema before the tool is seen by an agent.
- [Before Tool Execution](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/before-execution.mdx): These modifiers are called before the tool is executed by the LLM. This allows you to modify the _arguments_ called by the LLM before they are exec...
- [After Tool Execution](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/after-execution.mdx): These modifiers are called after the tool is executed by the LLM. This allows you to modify the _result_ of the tool before it is returned to the a...
- [Custom tools](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/custom-tools.mdx): A standalone tool is the simplest form of custom tool. It only requires input parameters and an execute function:
- [Custom Auth Configs](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/custom-auth-configs.mdx): Some apps, like PostHog, Hubspot, Linear, etc. allow customizing the auth config for your usage.
- [Programmatic Auth Configs](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/programmatic-auth-configs.mdx): Since OAuth2 is the most common authentication type for applications, Composio provides managed auth for most OAuth2 based applications.
- [Custom Auth Parameters](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/custom-auth-params.mdx): First, initialize the Composio SDK with your API key:
- [Using Triggers](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/using-triggers.mdx): Head to any app that supports triggers, such as Slack in the dashboard and enable the trigger of choice.
- [Composio MCP Servers](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/mcp-overview.mdx): Our MCP SDK features an intuitive, powerful, and developer-friendly API:
- [Developers](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/mcp-developers.mdx): - Create and Configure Toolkit permissions:
- [Partner Program](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/mcp-partner-api.mdx): As a partner, you receive:
- [Providers](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/mcp-providers.mdx): The Mastra Provider is tailored for the Mastra TypeScript-native agent framework. This client provides a getServer method to obtain the Composio MC...
- [Migration Guide](https://docs.composio.dev/docs/migration.mdx): A lot of the changes are on the infra side, but from the SDK point of view, here is what you can expect:
- [Basic Hono Server](https://docs.composio.dev/examples/sample-webserver.mdx): A simple example of a web server that uses the Composio SDK to call tools.
- [Full Stack Chat App](https://docs.composio.dev/examples/chat-app.mdx): Ensure you've followed the README.md in the composiohq/chat repository to set up the project locally.
- [AI Gmail Labeller](https://docs.composio.dev/examples/gmail-reaper.mdx): - Clone the filter-gmails-example repository and set the project up locally.
- [Tool Generator](https://docs.composio.dev/examples/tool-generator.mdx): An example that show you how to showcase auth scheme and action params for tools
- [OpenAI Provider](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/openai.mdx): By default, the OpenAI Provider is installed when you install the Composio SDK. You can also install it manually:
- [Anthropic Provider](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/anthropic.mdx): The Anthropic provider can be installed for both SDKs.
- [Google Provider](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/google.mdx): The Google Gen AI SDK and theprovider can only be installed for the Python SDK.
- [LangChain Provider](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/langchain.mdx): pip install composio_langchain==0.8.0 langchain
- [CrewAI Provider](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/crewai.mdx): The CrewAI Provider formats the Composio tools into an object compatible with CrewAI's tool calling capabilities. Agents and LLM workflows built wi...
- [Vercel AI SDK Provider](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/vercel.mdx): Vercel AI SDK and the provider are only available for the TypeScript SDK.
- [OpenAI Agents Provider](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/openai-agents.mdx): The OpenAI Agents Provider is a provider that formats the Composio tools into an object compatible with OpenAI's Agents API.
- [Mastra Provider](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/mastra.mdx): npm install @composio/mastra
- [TypeScript](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/custom/typescript.mdx): The Composio SDK uses a provider architecture to adapt tools for different AI frameworks. The provider handles:
- [Python](https://docs.composio.dev/providers/custom/python.mdx): The Composio SDK uses a provider architecture to adapt tools for different AI frameworks. The provider handles:
- [Introduction](https://docs.composio.dev/tools/introduction.mdx)
- [Premium Tools](https://docs.composio.dev/tools/src/premium-tools.mdx): Premium tools are essential tool calls that cost us more to run, normally paying for more premium services or longer running tasks.
